questions.text:
The type of cartilage shown in the image is found in:
  1. Thyroid cartilage
  2. Cricoid cartilage
  3. Corniculate cartilage
  4. Cuneiform cartilage
  5. Apices of arytenoids
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 3, 4 and 5 only. The above image shows elastic cartilage. It is seen in corniculate cartilage, cuneiform cartilage and apices of arytenoids. The given section is stained by Verhoeff’s method in which elastic fibres are stained bluish-black.

The elastic cartilage, like the hyaline cartilage, contains individual or small groups of chondrocytes that are surrounded by type II collagen fibrils. However, it differs from hyaline cartilage in that, much of the interterritorial matrix consists of fine yellow elastic fibres containing elastin protein and the surface of elastic cartilage is covered by perichondrium. On microscopy, elastic cartilage consists of:

  • Chondrocytes within lacunae
  • Elastic fibres in the matrix
  • Perichondrium with outer fibrous layer and the inner cellular layer

Elastic cartilage is found in:

  • External ear
  • External auditory meatus
  • Auditory tube
  • Corniculate cartilage
  • Cuneiform cartilage
  • Epiglottis
  • Apices of arytenoids

Thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage are composed of hyaline cartilage.

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Perichondrium Present (except at epiphyses & articular cartilage) Present Absent
Calcification Occurs with old age No calcification Occurs only with bone repair
Cells Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Fibroblasts & chondrocytes
Fibres Thin collagen Elastic fibres Thick collagen

questions.text: The posterior wall of the lesser sac is related to:
questions.solution:
The posterior wall of the lesser sac is related to the left suprarenal gland.

The lesser sac is a cavity lined with peritoneum and connected to the greater sac(main peritoneal cavity) by the epiploic foramen.

Superiorly, the peritoneum of the posterior wall of the lesser sac covers the following structures (from below upwards):

  • Pancreas
  • Upper pole of the left kidney
  • Left suprarenal gland
  • Abdominal aorta
  • Coeliac trunk
  • Diaphragm

Inferiorly, the posterior wall of the lesser sac is formed by the anterior layer of the posterior sheet of the greater omentum which covers the transverse mesocolon.

Related Pearl: Relations of epiploic foramen and lesser sac

questions.text: A young man presents to the casualty after a stab injury to the back and the muscles marked below are injured. What is the prime action of these muscles?
questions.solution:
The muscles marked in the above image are rhomboids minor and major. These muscles cause retraction of the scapula.

Rhomboids minor and major are innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve. They are supplied by the dorsal scapular artery or the deep branch of the transverse cervical artery.

Muscles involved in movements of the scapula are:

  • Protraction (forward movement): Serratus anterior and pectoralis minor are prime movers. Rhomboid muscles control the rate and range of movements. The upper part of the latissimus dorsi acts like a strap across the inferior scapular angle in protraction.
  • Retraction (backward movement): Middle trapezius and rhomboids.
  • Elevation: Trapezius, Levator scapulae.
  • Depression: Usually gravity alone is sufficient for the depression of the scapula. When required, a part of the serratus anterior, pectoralis minor, and trapezius are used.

questions.text: Reticular fibres are not present in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Reticular fibres are not present in the thymus.

Reticular fibres are fine, anastomosing fibres composed of mainly type III collagen. They differ from type I collagen fibres in that, they are finer and are arranged in the form of a network (reticulum). The fibres appear black in colour on staining with silver impregnation. Due to this affinity to silver salts, they are also known as argentophil fibres.

Reticular fibres are mainly found in:

  • All lymphoid organs like spleen, lymph node, and bone marrow (except thymus).
  • Glands, liver and kidneys.
  • The basement membrane of all epithelia.
  • Smooth muscle and nerve cells.

questions.text: During a routine dissection class, your professor asks you to identify the structures seen in the given specimen. Correctly match the following with their respective structures:

choices.text: 1- Putamen; 2- Globus pallidus; 3- Caudate nucleus; 4- Thalamus
1- Caudate nucleus; 2- Thalamus; 3- Globus pallidus; 4- Putamen
1- Thalamus; 2- Caudate nucleus; 3- Globus pallidus; 4- Putamen
1- Caudate nucleus; 2- putamen; 3- Thalamus; 4- Globus pallidus

questions.solution:
The correct match is: 1- Caudate nucleus, 2- Thalamus, 3- Globus pallidus, 4- Putamen. The given image shows the coronal section of the brain with different parts of the basal ganglia.

The basal ganglia constitutes accessory motor system that functions in close association with the cerebral cortex and corticospinal motor control system. On each side of the brain, these ganglia consist of the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus.

Nomenclature of basal ganglia:

  • Corpus striatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen+ globus pallidus
  • Lentiform nucleus: Putamen + globus pallidus
  • Neostriatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen 

The internal capsule separates the thalamus and the caudate nucleus from the lentiform nucleus. The caudate nucleus is a C-shaped mass of grey matter. It is divided into a head, body, and tail. Degeneration of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington's disease. 

Both the Putamen and external capsule lie lateral to globus pallidus. It receives fibers from the striatum and subthalamic nuclei. It acts as the main output of the basal ganglia to the thalamus and superior colliculus. The substantia nigra is seen in each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri. The levels of dopamine in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in parkinsonism disease.

questions.text:
Which of these sites have tanycytes and lack blood-brain barrier?
  1. Area postrema
  2. The suprafornical organ
  3. The supracommissural organ
  4. Organum vasculosum
  5. The anterior pituitary
questions.solution:
Area postrema and Organum vasculosum are circumventricular organs that have tanycytes and lack blood-brain barrier.

Tanycytes are specialized ependymal cells present in circumventricular organs. The functions of these ependymas and tanycytes include secretion of substances into the CSF, chemoreception, transport of neurochemicals from adjacent neurons, glial cells, or vessels to the CSF, and transport of neurochemicals from the CSF to the same adjacent structures.

The anterior pituitary has a normal blood-brain barrier. It is the posterior pituitary that lacks the blood-brain barrier.

Circumventricular organs (CVOs) are midline structures in the ventricular wall and are characterized by their extensive vasculature and lack of a normal blood-brain barrier (BBB). They are:

  • Area postrema
  • The subfornical organ
  • The subcommissural organ
  • Vascular organ of lamina terminalis (organum vasculosum)
  • The posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis)
  • The pineal gland
  • The median eminence

questions.text: The given area of the anterior surface of the left kidney is related to :
questions.solution:
The given area on the anterior surface of the left kidney is related to the jejunum.

 The anterior relations of the right kidney include:

  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Second/descending part of the duodenum
  • Liver
  • Hepatic flexure of the colon
  • Small intestine

The anterior relations of the left kidney include:

  • Left suprarenal gland 
  • Stomach
  • Pancreas
  • Jejunum
  • Spleen
  • Splenic flexure and the beginning of the descending colon

The posterior relations of the kidneys are as follows:

  • Vessels (1): Subcostal vessels
  • Ligaments (2): Medial and Lateral Arcuate ligaments
  • Nerves (3): Subcostal, Iliohypogastric, and Ilioinguinal nerves
  • Muscles (4): Diaphragm, Psoas major, Quadratus lumborum, and Transverses abdominis.
  • The right kidney is related to the 12th rib and the left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th ribs

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient is posted for an inguinal hernia operation. The anesthetist intends to use a regional anesthesia technique that blocks the nerves in the anterior abdominal wall. Between which of the following structures would the anesthetist be injecting the drug mixture?

choices.text: Between internal oblique and external oblique
Between internal oblique and rectus abdominis
Between internal oblique and transversus abdominis

questions.solution:
The local anesthetic is injected between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles in the anterior abdominal wall. This is because the neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies between these two muscles.

The transversus abdominis plane (TAP) block is a regional anesthetic technique for abdominal surgery. 

The neurovascular plane of the abdominal wall lies between the internal oblique and transversus abdominis in the anterior abdominal wall.

The plane contains:

  • Lower 6 thoracic nerves (T7-12)
  • Iliohypogastric nerves
  • Posterior intercostal and subcostal vessels
  • Anastomosis between superior and inferior epigastric arteries

questions.text: A middle-aged man who presented with an abdominal mass has the following subcutaneous venous circulation with the direction of the flow as depicted by the arrows in the image. This can be seen in:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the upward flow of subcutaneous venous circulation can be seen in inferior vena cava obstruction.

The level of the umbilicus is a watershed area for venous and lymphatic circulation. The systemic veins anastomose with tributaries of portal veins at the umbilicus. Normally, venous blood and lymphatics flow upwards above the plane of the umbilicus and downwards below this plane. 

  • In inferior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal wall is completely upward.
  • In superior vena cava obstruction, the blood flow in the veins of the anterior abdominal veins is completely downward.
  • In portal hypertension with dilated abdominal veins, the blood flow is away from the umbilicus, radiating like a star from the umbilicus (caput-medusae).

Causes of superior and inferior vena caval obstruction:

Causes of SVC obstruction Causes of IVC obstruction 

 

1. Mediastinal malignancy

2. Mediastinal fibrosis

3. Retrosternal thyroid

4. Aortic aneurysm

5. Radiation fibrosis

6. Iatrogenic
  1.  Thrombosis extension
  2.  Tumor invasion
  3.  Extrinsic compression (Eg: Pregnancy, abdominal mass)
  4. Coagulopathy
  5. Sepsis, dehydration, immobility
  6. Iatrogenic

Splenic vein thrombosis is one of the prehepatic causes of portal hypertension, in which the portal venous system is affected before it enters the liver.

questions.text: A 19-year-old football player was brought to the hospital after he suffered an ​injury caused by a lateral blow to the knee joint. MRI revealed an injury to the ligaments commonly referred to as the 'unhappy triad'. Which of the following ligaments are involved?

choices.text: Posterior cruciate ligament and lateral meniscus
Anterior cruciate ligament and medial meniscus
Anterior and posterior horns of lateral meniscus

questions.solution:
The unhappy triad of the knee involves:

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

Related Pearl: Unhappy triad of knee joint

It is also called O'Donoghue's triad/ terrible triad/ horrible triad of the knee. It mostly occurs in football, basketball & rugby players, due to a lateral blow to the knee.

It is characterized by injury to: 

  • Medial meniscus
  • Anterior cruciate ligament
  • Tibial collateral ligament

(Mnemonic – MAT)

The image below shows the unhappy triad of the knee joint on MRI (PDW SPIR):

  1. Rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament
  2. Rupture of the medial collateral ligament
  3. Inner meniscal tear (image shows complex rupture of the posterior horn).

questions.text: A patient underwent angioplasty with a Sirolimus-eluting stent in the anterior interventricular artery. This artery is a branch of:
questions.solution:
The anterior interventricular artery is a branch of the left coronary artery.

The left coronary artery arises from the left aortic sinus (left posterior sinus) of the ascending aorta. It passes between the pulmonary trunk and the left auricle and then runs in the coronary sulcus. It divides into its two terminal branches in the coronary sulcus. They are:

  • Anterior interventricular branch - also called the left anterior descending artery (LAD).
  • Circumflex branch - It gives a left marginal artery also called the obtuse marginal artery supplying the left ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not pass through the foramen marked with the black arrow in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The foramen marked in the image is the foramen ovale. The middle meningeal artery does not pass through the foramen ovale. It passes through the foramen spinosum.

The structures passing through the foramen ovale are:

  • Mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve 
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins 

These structures can be remembered using the mnemonic 'MALE'.   

The structures passing through the foramen spinosum are:

  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus (meningeal branch of mandibular nerve)
  • Middle meningeal vein

questions.text: A patient is not able to perform the test shown in the image given below. Which of the following nerves could be injured?
questions.solution:
The picture shows the card test, which tests adduction by palmar interossei. The ulnar nerve could be injured in this patient who is not able to perform the test.

In the card test, Examiner inserts a card between two extended fingers of the patient. He asks to hold it tightly as possible while he tries to pull the card back. Due to loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles patient is unable to hold a card between the fingers. This test is used for detecting ulnar nerve injury.

 

The ulnar nerve supplies the hypothenar muscles, all the palmar and dorsal interossei, and medial two lumbricals. Superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis, skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of the deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

Mnemonic for the action of interossei: PAD and DAB - palmar interossei cause adduction and dorsal interossei cause abduction of the fingers.

questions.text: A specimen of the posterior surface of the larynx is kept in an anatomy practical exam and a structure is marked with red. What would be the action of the structure?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the posterior view of the larynx and the marked muscle is the posterior cricoarytenoid. Its action is to abduct the vocal cords and open the glottis. The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is identified by its origin from the posterior surface of the cricoid. 

The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle arises from the posterior surface of the cricoid lamina and is attached to the upper and posterior surfaces of the muscular processes of the ipsilateral arytenoids. It is innervated by a branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. They are active in the production of unvoiced sounds.

The image below shows the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

questions.text: A radiologist is performing an ultrasound of the parotid gland in a case of parotid abscess. Which of the following structures will he not visualize within the gland?
questions.solution:
The facial artery is not present within the parotid gland 

The parotid gland contains:

Arteries:

  • External carotid artery, which terminates into the maxillary artery and superficial temporal artery.
  • The transverse facial artery, which is a branch of the superficial temporal artery.

Sometimes the external carotid artery may also give posterior auricular artery within the gland.

Veins:

Maxillary vein and superficial temporal vein, which unite to form the retromandibular vein.

Nerves:

Facial nerve and its branches and parotid lymph nodes

questions.text: A patient presented with tenderness in the region shown below following a fall onto an outstretched hand. Which of the following forms the roof of this region?
questions.solution:
The marked region is the anatomical snuffbox. The superficial branch of radial nerve forms the roof of the anatomical snuffbox. Tenderness in this region is suggestive of a scaphoid fracture, a common injury after a fall on an outstretched hand.

Anatomical snuffbox boundaries: 

Lateral wall:

  • Abductor pollicis longus (APL),
  • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)  

Medial wall:

  • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL).

Roof:

  • Cephalic vein
  • Superficial branch of radial nerve

Floor:

  • Radial styloid, Scaphoid, Trapezium, and 1st Metacarpal. 

Only content: Radial artery

The name "snuffbox" originates from the use of this surface for placing and then sniffing powdered tobacco, or snuff.

questions.text: You are evaluating a cyanotic newborn with an echocardiogram showing pulmonic stenosis involving the root of the pulmonary artery. Which developmental structure's defective maturation is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
This newborn is found to have pulmonic stenosis involving the root of the pulmonary artery. The structure which gives rise to the root of the pulmonary artery is the truncus arteriosus which is marked as '4' in the given image.

Structures marked:

  1. Sinus venosus
  2. Atrium
  3. Bulbus cordis
  4. Truncus arteriosus

The heart tube begins to bend by day 23. This bending creates the cardiac loop which is completed by day 28. The fate of various structures formed as a result of this bending is as follows:

Given below are the heart tube and their derivatives:

 Part of the heart tube Derivative structure in the heart

Bulbus cordis

questions.text:
Arrange the following events of embryonal development during the second to the fourth week in the sequence in which they occur:
  1. Formation of the neural plate
  2. Formation of the notochordal process
  3. Formation of the primitive streak 
  4. Notochordal plate separates from endoderm to form true notochord
  5. Formation of the notochordal plate
questions.solution:
The correct sequence in which the above events occur is 3, 2, 1, 5, 4: Formation of the primitive streak, notochordal process, neural plate, notochordal plate, and finally, the notochordal plate separates from the endoderm to form the true notochord.

The primitive streak is formed around day 15. This is followed by the formation of definitive endoderm and the formation of mesoderm.

This mesoderm extends cranially to form the notochordal process around day 17. Meanwhile, the mesoderm present lateral to midline gets divided into paraxial, intermediate, and lateral plate mesoderm. The lateral plate mesoderm splits into two layers- somatic mesoderm and splanchnic mesoderm, separated by the intraembryonic coelom.

Formation of the neural plate begins between days 19 and 20. The cranial and caudal parts of the neural plate represent the future brain and spinal cord, respectively.

The notochordal process fuses transiently with the endoderm to form a notochordal plate after day 20. Finally, around day 22, the notochordal plate separates from the endoderm to form a solid, definitive notochord.

  2. Protrusion of the mandible
  3. Side-to-side movement
  4. Elevation of the mandible
  5. Retraction of the mandible
questions.solution:
The marked area is the pterygoid fovea where the lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted. The action of this muscle is depression, protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the jaw. In addition to the pterygoid fovea, the lateral pterygoid muscle is also inserted into the articular disc and capsule of the temporomandibular joint. 

The lateral pterygoid muscle has 2 heads. The upper head originates from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head originates from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate.

questions.text: A patient sustained a vertebral fracture. On examination, he had bilateral spastic paralysis and bilateral loss of pain, temperature, and a light touch below the level of the lesion. Tactile discrimination, vibratory and proprioceptive sensations were preserved. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is anterior cord syndrome.

Anterior cord syndrome results from ischemia of the anterior spinal artery, and predominantly affects the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord. This can be caused by cord contusion due to vertebral fracture, dislocation, or by a herniated intervertebral disc. The clinical features seen after the period of spinal shock are:

1. Bilateral lower motor neuron paralysis in the segment of the lesion and muscular atrophy. This is caused by damage to neurons in the anterior grey columns and the anterior nerve roots of the same segment.

2. Bilateral spastic paralysis below the level of the lesion due to the involvement of anterior corticospinal tracts on both sides. The spasticity is produced by the interruption of tracts other than the corticospinal tracts.

3. Bilateral loss of pain, temperature, and light touch sensations below the level of the lesion due to anterior and lateral spinothalamic tract involvement on both sides.

4. Tactile discrimination and vibratory and proprioceptive sensations are preserved as the posterior white columns on both sides are intact.

Other options:

Option A: Complete cord transection results in complete loss of all sensation and voluntary movements below the level of the lesion.

  • The loss of tactile discrimination,  vibratory and proprioceptive sensations is due to bilateral destruction of the ascending tracts in the posterior white columns.
  • The loss of pain, temperature and light touch sensations is due to destruction of the lateral and anterior spinothalamic tracts.

Option B: Central cord syndrome occurs due to damage to the central region of the spinal cord. It commonly occurs due to cord compression between the vertebral body and a bulging ligamentum flavum.

  • There is bilateral lower motor neuron paralysis and muscular atrophy in the segment of the lesion.
  • Bilateral spasticity, loss of pain, temperature, light touch, and pressure sensations occur below the level of the lesion with characteristic sacral sparing. 
  • The lower limb fibers are less affected than the upper limb fibers.

Option D: Brown-Sequard syndrome results from hemisection of the spinal cord due to traumatic injuries. Clinical features include: 

  • Ipsilateral lower motor neuron paralysis in the segment of the lesion, muscular atrophy, an ipsilateral band of cutaneous anesthesia in the segment of the lesion
  • Ipsilateral loss of tactile discrimination and vibratory and proprioceptive sensations below the level of the lesion.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensations below the level of the lesion and contralateral incomplete loss of tactile sensation below the level of the lesion.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with immune thrombocytopenic purpura is undergoing elective splenectomy. During the procedure, injury to which of the following ligaments can lead to a complication of pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Injury to the splenorenal ligament during splenectomy can lead to pancreatitis as it contains the tail of pancreas. Other complications include bleeding and pancreatic fistula formation.

questions.text: A female patient comes to you with complaints of midline neck swelling. You proceed to perform the thyroid examination and ask her to swallow. The thyroid mass moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by which of the following fascia?

choices.text: Investing layer of the deep cervical fascia

questions.solution:
The thyroid mass moves with swallowing because the thyroid gland is enclosed by the pre-tracheal fascia.

Pre-tracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. Pretracheal fascia is attached to the larynx and this attachment is responsible for the movement of the enlarged thyroid gland on deglutition.

The ligament of Berry, also called the suspensory ligament extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid. It is formed by the condensation of the pre-tracheal fascia. Its attachment prevents the thyroid gland from sinking down into the mediastinum.

Related Pearl: Modifications of Deep cervical fascia

The deep fascia in the neck is condensed to form the following layers:

Investing layer - It forms the roof of the posterior triangle and splits to enclose:

  • Parotid gland
  • Submandibular gland

Pretracheal fascia - It splits to enclose the thyroid gland to form its false capsule. This capsule is thickened posteriorly and on either side forms the suspensory ligament which is known as the ligament of Berry.

Carotid sheath - is formed anteriorly by pre tracheal fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia. It encloses:

  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve 

Prevertebral fascia - It forms the floor of the posterior triangle and the axillary sheath. Inferiorly, it blends with the anterior longitudinal ligament.

Buccopharyngeal fascia - It covers the outer surface of the pharyngeal constrictors and the buccinator. Posteriorly, it's separated from the prevertebral fascia by the retropharyngeal space.

Pharyngobasilar fascia - It fills the gap between superior constrictor and base of the skull.

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ________type of joint.
questions.solution:
The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.

In ball and socket type of joints, the articular surfaces include a globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket. These joints are multi-axial and movements occur around a number of axes. Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, medial rotation, lateral rotation, and circumduction, all occur quite freely. E.g., shoulder joint, hip joint, talocalcaneonavicular joint, and incudostapedial joint.

In the talocalcaneonavicular joint, the ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus. The socket is formed by 3 structures, the posterior surface of the navicular, the anterior articular surface of the calcaneus, and the upper surface of the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament).

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient is undergoing a clinical assessment for aphasia. He is unable to name the objects properly and fails to repeat sentences as told. The speech is otherwise effortless and melodic. He makes errors in word choice frequently like he uses incorrect words like 'den' for 'pen', associated with neologism, and sentences are incomprehensible. Which area of brain damage can result in such a type of aphasia?
questions.solution:
The patient described most likely has Wernicke’s aphasia due to the damage to Wernicke’s area - area 22. It is the sensory speech area located in the temporal lobe.

In Wernicke's aphasia, there is difficulty in finding words leading to poorly understood content for the listener. These patients also find it difficult to repeat sentences and name things properly. It is a type of fluent aphasia in which the speech is easy and fluent but there are difficulties related to the output of language like paraphasia (substitution of similar-sounding, non-words, or incorrect words). The speech is full of jargon and neologisms (non-existent words) that make little sense.

Area 44 and 45 are Broca’s areas, which are motor speech areas. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of functional words. However, comprehension of speech is intact and the patient knows what he wants to say.

questions.text: An intern was asked to give an intravenous injection to a vein in the cubital fossa. All of the following are true about the cubital fossa except:

choices.text: Musculocutaneous nerve is one of the contents
Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally
Median cubital vein forms the roof

questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true about the cubital fossa except the musculocutaneous nerve is one of the contents.

The cubital fossa is a triangular depression present in the anterior side of the elbow joint. The boundaries of the cubital fossa include medially by the lateral border of the pronator teres, laterally by the medial border of the brachioradialis (option A), the base is formed proximally by an imaginary line joining the epicondyles of the humerus and the apex is pointed downwards by joining of the lateral and medial boundaries.

The roof is formed by the skin, superficial fascia containing median cubital vein (option D) joining the cephalic and basilic veins, lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, medial cutaneous nerve of the forearm, bicipital aponeurosis, and deep fascia. The floor is formed by brachialis and supinator muscles.

The contents of the brachial fossa are (from medial to lateral side):

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery, terminating into radial and ulnar arteries
  • Biceps brachii tendon with the bicipital aponeurosis
  • Radial nerve enters the fossa laterally (option C) in the groove between the brachialis and brachioradialis

Clinical significance:

  • The median cubital vein is the most commonly preferred vein of choice for intravenous injections. 
  • Auscultation of the brachial artery in front of the elbow helps in measuring the blood pressure.

questions.text:
Match the embryological origin with their derivatives.
            Embryological origin                 Derivatives 

      a) Septum transversum

      1) Hepatogastric ligament

      b) Dorsal pancreatic bud

       2) Duct of santorini

      c) Ventral pancreatic bud

       3) Kupffer cells
      d) Ventral mesogastrium       4) Gastrophrenic ligament
      e) Dorsal mesogastrium       5) Uncinate process
questions.solution:
All the above structures are the embryological of the digestive system. The liver bud, ventral pancreatic bud and dorsal pancreatic bud arise from the foregut, ventral mesogastrium arises from the septum transversum and dorsal mesogastrium arises from the lateral plate mesoderm. 

Ventral and dorsal mesogastrium develop into the peritoneal connections in the abdomen which are together called ventral and dorsal mesentery. 

Liver is developed by the septum transversum and the hepatic bud.

Ventral and dorsal pancreatic buds give rise to the pancreas and the pancreatic ducts. When the duodenum rotates to the right to form a “C” shape, the ventral pancreatic bud moves dorsally. It moves such that it comes to lie immediately below and behind the dorsal pancreatic bud. Later the parenchyma and the ducts of both the buds fuse. Development of pancreas is as shown in the below image.

Embryological origin of foregut structures

5) Dorsal pancreatic bud

questions.text: A surgeon has been performing a difficult neck dissection for the past 3 hours. During the procedure, he has accidentally injured the hypoglossal nerve. Which of the following triangles of the neck, is he probably dissecting?
questions.solution:
The surgeon has accidentally injured the hypoglossal nerve, which has its major course in the carotid triangle.

The hypoglossal nerve leaves the skull through the hypoglossal canal. It then descends to the carotid triangle. Here, in the carotid triangle, the nerve makes a loop lateral to the internal and external carotid arteries. The nerve then ascends to the digastric triangle, reaches further up supplying the muscles of the tongue.

Contents of the carotid triangle:

  • Common carotid artery, internal and external carotid artery
  • Branches of external carotid – superior thyroid, lingual, facial, ascending pharyngeal, and occipital artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Spinal part of the accessory
  • Sympathetic chain
  • Ansa cervicalis

questions.text: An infant has a noticeable small mandible and cleft palate. A CT scan reveals hypoplasia of the mandible and a defect in the ​middle ear cavity and tympanic membrane. A developmental defect of which pharyngeal arch will result in these defects?
questions.solution: Agenesis of the first pharyngeal arch results in hypoplasia of the mandible and the middle ear ossicles (malleus and incus) causing conduction deafness.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with sudden onset dysarthria and impaired sensation over the right side of her face. Further examination shows loss of pain and temperature on the left side of the body. When asked to walk in a straight line, she sways to the right side. Which of the following marked vessels is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome/Wallenberg syndrome. This may result from a stroke affecting the ipsilateral (right-sided, in this case) vertebral artery marked as '4' in the image above.

Lateral medullary syndrome: The clinical findings correspond to the neuroanatomical structures affected in the lateral portion of the medulla:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal)- loss of pain and sensation over the ipsilateral half of face.
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle – ipsilateral ataxia (gait and limb)
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract – loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body. 
  • IX and X CN - ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysphagia, dysarthria.
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Descending sympathetic tract – ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).

The lateral medullary syndrome may also occur as a consequence of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) stroke. PICA is a branch of the vertebral artery.

 

Other options:

The other structures marked in the image are as follows - 

1 - Anterior cerebral artery

2 - Middle cerebral artery

3 - Basilar cerebral artery

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of severe pain in her buttocks because of the inflammation of the muscle marked in the image below. Which of the following nerves is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is the piriformis. When piriformis muscle gets inflamed, there is compression of the sciatic nerve which leads to piriformis syndrome characterised by pain along distribution of the sciatic nerve. 

Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle. This can occur due to inflammation of the piriformis muscle. The patient will present with pain along the distribution of the sciatic nerve which is also known as sciatica. It is triggered by sitting for a long time or running, climbing stairs, or applying firm pressure directly over the piriformis muscle which puts pressure over the underlying the sciatic nerve and causes pain along the distibution of the nerve thereof.

Early signs include pain, tingling, or numbness in the buttocks. Later it may lead to severe pain extending down the length of the sciatic nerve.

questions.text: During routine dissection classes, you and your friend are discussing the cadaveric specimen of the inferior surface of the liver. Which of the following lobe is referred to as segment I?
questions.solution:
The lobe marked as '3' in the above image represents the caudate lobe which is referred to as segment I.

Couinaud's segmental division of the liver is the functional division based on the portal venous branches in the parenchyma. They are divided into 8 functional segments. The caudate lobe corresponds to segment I of Couinaud's segments.

The caudate lobe of the liver has a portal blood supply and hepatic vein drainage independent of the remainder of the liver and also forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen. 

The caudate lobe is visible as prominent on the inferior and posterior surfaces of the liver. It lies posterior to the porta hepatis and to its right is the groove for the inferior vena cava.

Other markings:

1-Quadrate lobe

2-Right lobe

4-Left Lobe

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

questions.text: An elderly female patient presented with signs and symptoms of essential tremor caused due to progressive degeneration of the cells that form the output of the cerebellar cortex. Which of the following cells are affected?
questions.solution:
Purkinje cells are the affected cells in this patient as they form the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei(Fastigial, Globose, Emboliform, and Dentate).

The Purkinje layer is the middle layer of the cerebellar cortex. It contains flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the deep cerebellar nuclei.

The output from the  whole cerebellum is from deep cerebellar nuclei

  • Globose, emboliform, and dentate nuclei give output via superior cerebellar peduncle
  • Fastigial nuclei give output via inferior cerebellar peduncle

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar Circuitry

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

  • Climbing fibers -
    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle
    • Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text:
Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery?
  1. Superior gluteal artery
  2. Inferior gluteal artery
  3. Superior vesical artery
  4. Middle rectal artery
  5. Inferior vesical artery
  6. Vaginal artery
questions.solution:
The branches from the anterior division include 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

 

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  1. Obturator artery
  2. Superior vesical artery
  3. Inferior vesical artery 
  4. Inferior gluteal artery
  5. Middle rectal artery
  6. Vaginal artery (in females)
  7. Uterine artery (in females)
  8. Internal pudendal artery

Branches of the posterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries
  • Superior gluteal artery

questions.text: A first-year medical student is doing a meticulous dissection of the thoracic cage in a human cadaver. During dissection, he sees an osseo-aponeurotic opening in the diaphragm transmitting a large vessel. Which among the following other structures can be seen passing through the same opening?

choices.text: Left vagus nerve and thoracic duct
Right vagus nerve and thoracic duct

questions.solution:
The osseo-aponeurotic opening in the diaphragm transmits the aorta. The other structures which pass through the same opening are the azygous vein and the thoracic duct. 

It is the most posteroinferior of the three larger openings in the diaphragm and lies at the level of the T12 vertebra. It is bounded laterally by the two diaphragmatic crura, the vertebral column posteriorly, and anteriorly by the median arcuate ligament.

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

Major openings through the diaphragm

Level of opening

T8

T10

T12

Located in

In the central tendon

In the muscular part

In crus of the diaphragm

Structures passing through

 

Inferior Vena cava

Right phrenic nerve 

Oesophagus

Vagus nerve- right and left

Aorta

Thoracic duct

Azygous vein

Hemiazygous vein

 

Minor openings through the diaphragm

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery
  • Medial arcuate ligament - Sympathetic chain
  • Lateral arcuate ligament - Subcostal nerves and vessels

 

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: An elderly man with atherosclerosis presented with abdominal pain and blood-stained stools.  CECT abdomen is suggestive of ischemic colitis at the splenic flexure involving the marginal artery of Drummond. What are the arteries contributing to the formation of this structure?

choices.text: Right colic and left colic arteries
Left colic and middle colic arteries

questions.solution:
The middle and left colic arteries contribute to the formation of the marginal artery of Drummond at the splenic flexure. The splenic flexure (Griffith's point) is a watershed area of the colon which is more prone to ischemia. 

The anastomotic vessel that runs in the mesentery along the inner margin of the colon is called the marginal artery of Drummond. From this artery, numerous small branches are given to the large bowel. It is formed by:

  • Branches of superior mesenteric artery - middle colic, right colic, and ileocolic arteries
  • Branches of inferior mesenteric artery - left colic, sigmoid, and superior rectal arteries

When ischemia occurs at Griffith's point, the blood supply in this region is augmented by another arterial loop called the inner arterial arc (of Riolan). This arc connects the main trunk of the middle colic artery with the ascending branch of the left colic artery.

Note: Sudeck's point is another watershed area present at the rectosigmoid junction. The sigmoid artery anastomoses with the superior rectal artery at this site.

questions.text: A first-year medical student during his practical exam was given with 1st rib and asked to name the structures related to it. The neck of the 1st rib is related to all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The internal thoracic artery is not related to the neck of the first rib.

The structures related to neck of the first rib (medial to lateral):

  • Sympathetic trunk
  • Vein ( posterior intercostal)
  • Artery (superior intercostal)
  • Nerve (T1 nerve)

These structures are also related to the apex of lung anteriorly.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the pelvis was diagnosed with urethral rupture. Imaging revealed extravasation of the urine into the superficial perineal pouch. The attachment of which ​of the following fascia prevents extravasation into the thigh and anal triangle?
questions.solution:
Colle's fascia prevents the extravasation of the urine from spreading into the thigh and anal triangle. 

Scarpa's fascia is continuous with the superficial fascia of the scrotum and becomes the Colles' fascia. In women, it continues into the labia majora and is continuous with the fascia of the perineum. Colle's fascia has the following attachments:

  • Posterior - perineal membrane. It prevents the extravasation of fluids such as blood, pus, or urine into the anal triangle. 
  • Lateral - ischiopubic rami and fascia lata along Holden's line. This line extends from the pubic tubercle laterally for 8 cm. It prevents the extravasation of fluids into the thigh. 

Option A: Camper's fascia is the superficial fatty layer of the superficial fascia of the abdomen.

Option B: Scarpa's fascia is the deep membranous layer of the superficial fascia of the abdomen.

Option C: Buck's fascia is the deep fascia of the penis 

Clinical significance:

When a urethral injury occurs, urine can extravasate into the superficial perineal pouch, penis, scrotum, labia majora and the anterior abdominal wall.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came to the orthopedic outpatient unit for follow-up of his right tibial fracture that was managed with a plaster cast. The doctor observes that the patient lifts his right leg high to take a step. On examination, the right foot is inverted and there is no sensation perceived on the whole dorsum of the right foot. Which nerve is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The nerve affected in this patient is the common fibular nerve (common peroneal nerve)

The common fibular nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the 4th - 5th lumbar and 1st-2nd sacral ventral rami. The sciatic nerve divides into the tibial nerve and the common fibular nerve.

The common fibular nerve runs obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the fibular head. It lies between the biceps femoris and lateral head of the gastrocnemius. It then curves laterally around the neck of the fibula and gets divided into superficial and deep fibular nerves.

Superficial fibular nerve 

Motor innervation: 

  • Peroneus longus
  • Peroneus brevis

Sensory innervation: 

  • Lateral aspect of the lower leg
  • Dorsum of the toes except for the lateral side of the 5th toe and the first interdigital webspace

Deep fibular nerve

Motor innervation:

  • Extensor digitorum longus
  • Extensor hallucis longus
  • Tibialis anterior
  • Peroneus tertius

Sensory innervation:

  • The first interdigital space

History of plaster cast implies compression of the common fibular nerve resulting in foot drop (which causes high stepping gait), loss of eversion of the foot, and sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot.

Other options:

Option B- Superficial fibular nerve causes inverted foot and sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot but not foot drop.

Option C- Deep fibular nerve causes sensory loss only in the first interdigital cleft. It also causes weakness of ankle dorsiflexion and extension of all toes. 

Option D- Sural nerve gives cutaneous innervation to the posterolateral aspect of the distal third of the leg and the lateral aspect of the foot, heel and ankle.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the phrenic nerve except that :

choices.text: It is a purely motor nerve
It arises mainly from C4 spinal nerve
It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior
The right phrenic nerve passes through the vena caval opening

questions.solution:
All of the following are true about the phrenic nerve except option A as it is a mixed nerve (sensory and motor nerve).

Each phrenic nerve provides the sole motor supply to its hemidiaphragm. In its thoracic course, each phrenic nerve supplies sensory branches to the mediastinal pleura, fibrous pericardium, and parietal serous pericardium.

The phrenic nerve is a mixed nerve derived mostly from the C4 ramus and also receives contributions from the C3 and C5 ventral rami.

It is formed at the lateral border of the scalenus anterior. At the root of the neck, the right phrenic nerve runs anterior to the second part of the right subclavian artery from which it is separated by scalenus anterior muscle. The phrenic nerve lies posterior to the right subclavian vein.

The right phrenic nerve is shorter and more vertical than the left. The right phrenic nerve passes through the vena caval opening. The left phrenic nerve passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm just anterior to the central tendon.

The phrenic nerve is responsible for the referred pain which usually occurs when there is inflammation of the diaphragmatic pleura, e.g. in basal pneumonia, pleural effusions, or with irritation of the peritoneal pleura, as with a subphrenic abscess. It is frequently felt at the tip of the shoulder due to the common root of origin of the phrenic nerve and the nerves supplying the shoulder.

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

T12

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery
  • Medial arcuate ligament - Sympathetic chain
  • Lateral arcuate ligament - Subcostal nerves and vessels

questions.text: A middle-aged woman was undergoing cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the resident accidentally advanced the scissors along the epiploic foramen and worried she might have injured the structures around it. All are true about the boundaries of the epiploic foramen except:

choices.text: Posteriorly -  Aorta and origin of celiac trunk

questions.solution:
Posterior relation of epiploic foramen does not include aorta and origin of celiac trunk.

Epiploic foramen is posteriorly related to inferior vena cava, right suprarenal gland, and body of T12 vertebra. Commencement of abdominal aorta and celiac trunk forms posterior relation of the lesser sac and not of Epiploic foramen. 

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac) is a short vertical slit situated behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac.

Boundaries of epiploic foramen are:

  • Anterior – Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, bile duct.
  • Posterior – Body of T12 vertebra, Inferior vena cava, right adrenal gland.
  • Superior – Caudate lobe of the liver.
  • Inferior – First part of the duodenum and the horizontal part of the hepatic artery.

Related Pearl: Relations of epiploic foramen and lesser sac

Relations of epiploic foramen:

Anterior
  • Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein, and common bile duct

Posterior
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Body of T12 vertebra

Superior
  • Caudate lobe of the liver

Inferior
  • 1st part of duodenum

 

Relations of lesser sac:

Anterior
  • Caudate lobe of liver
  • Lesser omentum
  • Stomach
  • First 2 layers of the greater omentum

Posterior

Structures forming the stomach bed:

  • Pancreas
  • Splenic artery
  • Left kidney and suprarenal gland
  • Commencement of abdominal aorta and coeliac artery
  • Left crus of the diaphragm
  • Splenic flexure of the colon
  • Transverse mesocolon

Superior
  • Reflection of the peritoneum from the esophagus to the diaphragm

Inferior
  • Continuation of 2nd and 3rd layers of the greater omentum

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the structure marked as X in the image?

choices.text: It passes from external iliac artery to the umbilicus

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the medial umbilical fold. It overlies the obliterated umbilical artery.

The peritoneum of the lower anterior abdominal wall is raised into five folds that diverge as they descend from the umbilicus. These include:

Umbilical folds Features
Median umbilical fold

Single, present in the midline

Extends from the umbilicus to the apex of the bladder

Remnant of the urachus
Medial umbilical folds

Two in number

Extends from the internal iliac artery to the umbilicus

Overlies the obliterated umbilical artery
Lateral umbilical folds

Two in number

Overlies the inferior epigastric vessels

questions.text: Identify trabeculae in the following image below showing histological section of lymph node:
questions.solution:
Structure marked as 5 is trabeculae in the given histological image of lymph node.

The structures marked in the above histological section of the lymph node are as follows:

  • Capsule
  • Subcapsular sinus
  • Germinal centre
  • Lymphoid nodule
  • Trabeculae

Histology of lymph node:

Each lymph node consists of a connective tissue framework and of numerous lymphocytes of all types which are arranged in a stroma of reticulin fibers and cells to form 3 major regions within each Lymph node:

  • Outer zone known as Cortex which contains Subcapsular sinuses, Lymphoid nodules and densely packed lymphocytes, and therefore stains darkly. Each nodule has a paler staining germinal centre surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. 
  • A deeper extension of cortex called the paracortex , which lacks nodules. and has fewer lymphocytes, therefore, lighter staining
  • And a medulla (lighter staining zone in which lymphocytes are fewer) with prominent draining sinusoids adjacent to the hilum.

questions.text: The given epithelium in the histological image is not found in
questions.solution:
The above image shows transitional epithelium, identified by the variations in the cell layers: The deepest cell layer is columnar, the middle is made of polyhedral cells and lastly the surface cells are large and umbrella-shaped. Transitional epithelium lines the pre-prostatic and prostatic part of the urethra (not the membranous urethra).  

Transitional epithelium is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and the pre-prostatic and prostatic part of the urethra. Because of this distribution, it is also called the urothelium.  

In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.  

The following are various parts of the urethra in males and their lining epithelium:

  • Pre-prostatic & Prostatic urethra: Transitional epithelium
  • Membranous urethra: Pseudostratified columnar
  • Penile/Spongy urethra: Proximally: Pseudostratified columnar, Distally: Stratified squamous

questions.text: A male patient was diagnosed with a submandibular gland tumour and posted for surgical removal of the gland along with its duct. Following surgery, he developed a loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, the taste sensations are present. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
General sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by the lingual nerve, which is likely to be injured in this case.

In the anterior two-thirds of the tongue,

  • General sensation is carried by the lingual nerve.
  • Taste sensation is carried by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.

In the posterior one-third of the tongue, both general and taste sensations are carried by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Valleculae are supplied by the internal laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve.

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue

Area

General sensory

Special sensory

Anterior 2/3rds

Lingual nerve (CN V)

Chorda tympani (CN VII)

Posterior 1/3rd

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Posterior most tongue (vallecullae, epiglottis)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

Internal laryngeal nerve (CN X)

questions.text: A 12-year-old presented with fever and difficulty swallowing. He had swelling in the marked region and was advised to undergo surgery. Post-surgery the gauze continued to soak with blood. Which of the following vessels must have been injured?
questions.solution:
The given image is a cadaveric specimen with the arrow pointing towards, the tonsillar fossa, and the given clinical vignette is suggestive of tonsillitis. Post tonsillectomy hemorrhage is commonly venous in origin, from the paratonsillar/ external palatine vein. 

Torrential hemorrhage can be due to injury to an aberrantly large or aberrantly placed tonsillar arterial branch of the facial artery.

Blood supply of the tonsils: 

Arterial supply:

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main supply.
  • Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.
  • Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery.
  • Descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery.

Venous supply:

  • Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.

Types of Hemorrhage seen during/post tonsillectomy:

  • Primary hemorrhage:
    • Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels.
    • Can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.
  • Reactionary hemorrhage:
    • It occurs within 24 hours of surgery.
    • It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal.
    • It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
    • If not controlled the patient is anesthetized and hemorrhage is managed by re-exploration.
  • Secondary hemorrhage:
    • It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th postoperative days).
    • It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.
    • The patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.

The images below summarize the blood supply to the tonsils and the relations of the tonsillar bed respectively.
